body: You will need to fix the errors with the CI services.
@Phrohdoh  Done, thanks!
I can only comment on coding style and things I do not comprehend so I will stay out of this until someone more knowledgeable comes along.
The performance improvements demonstrated at https://ci.appveyor.com/project/OpenRA/openra/build/1.0.927/tests are impressive.

It would be super helpful to get the changes from #7358 completed and accepted first, and then restrict perf improvement to its own PR (I guess this PR). Separating the two out makes things easier for others to review.

Edit: Previously had some more stuff written here I was wrong about and have removed, ignore my silliness :)

@RoosterDragon probably what makes the pathfinder to generate different paths is the comparison between gCost and Mincost inside expand. I added an equality comparison, because if it's equal then it's not worth to consider the neighbor.

Try replacing the >= by a > in the PathSearch class. It should give you same paths in exchange of a bit of performance.
@Mailaender those times in appveyor are strange because on my 5 year old machine the tests take 10 times less.

Those are slow Microsoft Azure virtual machines that are dedicated to the Open Source community for free so that does not surprise me. I mean the 2x improvements in speed of your new path finder compared to the legacy one in direct comparison using synthetic tests.

I played a couple of test games and didn't notice anything obviously off about the pathing. But I imagine there are plenty of edge cases others might be better at catching though.

I can confirm the perf improvements via profiling. Hopefully this means less lag spikes from pathing in practise.

If it's possible to construct a test that runs the new and old pathfinders and verifies the weighted path length matches for both that would be awesome as a way to verify nothing broke. Depends how easy such a thing is I guess.

@RoosterDragon given how difficult the upstream/bleed pathfinder was to test, I guess that the only way to test and veryfy that would be through integration tests. Given that the dependencies of PathFinder are Map, World, MobileInfo and an Actor inside, we would need to instantiate a real world for the test and make that Actor move to several locations. The problem is I'm not aware about how to instantiate them in an easy way from files.

Other than that, the LegacyPathFinder expand I have is the plain old Expand with some methods extracted to ease readability and several variables renaming to match most A\* documentation.

A few general style nits I noticed while scanning the code (ref: [coding standard](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/wiki/Coding-Standard)):
- Files must include our standard file header.
- Use `//` for single-line comments, and comments should start with a capital letter.
- Omit `private` from method and field declarations (it is the default).
- There are still a few places with space-indentation issues.
@Rydra : you sayed 80% ~90%, what is the case if you have more than 40 units and the AI is attacking to the same Time? =/

@LipkeGu that's why I would wish people to try my changes and get feedback. Yet on a couple of sample games I tried on my +5 years old machine and lots of units the results were interesting in terms of performance.

I did a quick (and not particularly scientific) test by counting and timing the number of long (greater than 1ms) pathfinding checks during one loop of the shellmap.  I did this by running the shellmap until the naval transport first appears at the bottom of my 900px vertical resolution, and then parsing the perf.log using `cat perf.log | awk '/Move/ { x += $1; y += 1 } END { print x, y }'`.

On current bleed I get about 440 long ticks adding to about 1.8 seconds of calculation time.
On this pr I get about 630 long ticks adding to about 3 seconds of calculation time.

This seems to indicate a ~50% perf hit on my machine (for these worst-case paths)!  I'm interested to see what results a proper profiling run shows.

@pchote I've run your command on 2 executions on this PR and upstream/bleed in the start screen until the second time the screen turns grey due to a beam, and I have obtained the following results:

(I guess the first value of your command tells the ms, and the second the number of occurrences).

upstream/pfoptim -> 2062  462
upstream/bleed -> 2340 - 443

As you said, I don't think this at all an accurate indicator because it just calculates the > 1ms moves.

i have tested this branch , played 2 maps so far ... 
http://resource.openra.net/maps/1024 (full with bots , ffa) 
http://resource.openra.net/maps/88/ (7 bots , 4v4) 

the good news , it did run pretty smooth without any significant speed-drop ... until (thats the bad news) (after a couple of minutes) , in both games , 2-3 hudge "tick activitie" spikes appeared ... which caused the game to freeze for a couple of seconds ... and on the last spike it was completly frozen and crashed 

i am playing on a pretty old laptop too , +4-5 years ... 

edit : nevermind , no crashlog at all ... 
i do have a crash-log ... but it shows me "version 1029" ...

@MicroJOo it's strange that in the stack trace there is no instruction related to movement or the Pathfinder (although I'm not fully aware about how Sync works). Could it be an issue not related to the Pathfinder?

I hope someone can shed some light.

i did what you said (you have to give me a cookie for that , it was the first time for me ) : 
![changed line](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6188811/49c8fd0c-b395-11e4-86b9-de0355959a4f.png)

but still , it crashed again ... on a smaller map , with only 5 bots ... here a screen from the spike before it actually crashed , problem is , it doesnt write any crash-report altough i end up with the "fatal error" window ... and i have to kill the process when its freezing ...  : 

![spike](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9139965/6188848/b15d4e50-b395-11e4-971d-6e5dde4208a7.png)

ill check our current bleed , if the same problem happens there
well ... i did "not" crash in bleed ... but i did crash every game on this branch here ... on 3 different maps , with 5-7 bots  ... around 10 minutes
Thanks for the feedback @MicroJOo. I'll profile your situation and check whether the same issues happen to me.

@MicroJOo I have good news. I've been able to reproduce and track down the problem you had. It was a problem with harvesters and the heuristic they use to determine the path they have to follow to arrive to the resources.

If you pull again it should work now. Thank for your feedback and happy testing!

I attach a couple of profiling comparisons between upstream/bleed and this PR. I've played a 6v6 game (11 bots and 1 human player) on a big map for 15 minutes.

Showing the function "EvalPath" that processes the path for a unit. Note the improvement inside the FindBidiPath function.

This profiling has proven to me that the current cache is quite useless. A better approach (under study) would be to pre-generate at map loading time a Shortest Path Tree for different unit classes and paths so every path from one point to another is covered and precalculated.

Another thing to consider is to integrate a hierarchical pathfinder approach to dramatically boost performance.

Bleed:
![bleed profile](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5826108/6204089/f86d661e-b53d-11e4-9fd9-baa798055055.jpg)

This PR: 
![pr profile](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5826108/6204091/febfdc18-b53d-11e4-8a72-c1a621412702.jpg)

That is a nice difference :)
And if the pre-calculated paths idea can be done to work in a reasonable time and not much memory overhead I think that'd be great.
Hello Rydra, how did you make those profiling benchmarks?

@deniz1a using Jetbrains DotTrace 6, student licensed.

Visual Studio provides its own profiling tool, but it's not as good.
@deniz1a : https://www.jetbrains.com/student/ In my apprenticeship we had to deploy this Programm for commercial & Student purposes :)

I leave here a nice article about RTS pathfinding that could be useful to research for whoever is interested in improving the pathfinder: http://aigamedev.com/open/tutorials/clearance-based-pathfinding/
